data.title: Markdown - Preview synchronization after save
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Win10 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start with new Markdown file (unsaved)
2. Open live preview
3. Create some content and save file

After saving the live preview of Markdown file is still connected to (now) nonexisting "unsaved" file. You have to close preview and open new one to see changes again...

Similar situation with **"Save as..."**

data.title: [typescript] Sintax Highlight breaks when a variable is assigned an object in a new line.
data.body:

- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Code. 
2. Open the attached example file SintaxHighlightBugReport.ts (inside the zip, github does not support ts attachments)
3. Observe that the method wronglyHighlitedCode is not correct in terms of highlighted code colors (is all white text). 

I've attached a screen grab too, in which I've marked the behavior I'm observing in my PC.

Hope this helps!

data.title: Cursor Up and Down should place the cursor at end of line if it's current state is end of line

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- Move the cursor to End of line by using `End` or `Cmd + Right` 
- Now doing Up or Down commands should place the cursor at the End.

But currently VS Code is placing the cursor at `min(previousPos, lineLength)`

data.title: C/C++ include <header_with_underscore> not found
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. install the C/C++ extension
2. set the include path correctly to the system headers' directory in c_cpp_properties.json
3. Create a new C++ file that includes e.g. `<array>` and `<type_traits>`
4. Observe that `<array>` is found, but `<type_traits>` not, although both being in the same directory.

![image1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14040010/17051916/6a5f16e2-4ffb-11e6-81a5-a60edd41ff9c.png)

Tested on Windows with Cygwin, Mingw64 and MSVC header directories. Same behaviour for all of them. Restarting VS Code doesn't solve the problem.

data.title: Ballistic scrolling on virtual widgets doesn't work when using touch

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Affected widgets:
- Editor
- Tree
- List

Steps:
- Using a touch device, scroll away a long list of elements.
- The scrolling will come to a complete stop once the element in which the touch event started goes out of the DOM.
- This is fixed when using the scroll wheel, we should implement the same when using touch.

data.title: Initial task loading is extremely slow with Gulp, even when using tasks.json
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1 and 1.4.0-insider 
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a folder in VS Code that uses Gulp as task runner and has a tasks.json that defines all the tasks
2. Type in the task command

![animation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10532611/17051431/06f6cfc0-4ff9-11e6-868e-e16b91a9e10c.gif)

This is running on a Surface Pro 3. Even on my PC it is slow though.
It seems like VS Code first runs Gulp to get a list of tasks even thought they are already all defined in tasks.json:

``` json
{
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "command": "gulp",
  "isShellCommand": true,
  "showOutput": "always",
  "tasks": [
    {
      "taskName": "ts",
      "problemMatcher": "$tsc"
    },
    {
      "taskName": "watch-ts",
      "isWatching": true,
      "problemMatcher": {
        "base": "$tsc-watch",
        "watchedTaskBeginsRegExp": "Starting",
        "watchedTaskEndsRegExp": "Finished"
      }
    },
    ...
  ]
}
```

I appreciate that VS Code asks Gulp to get tasks that may not have been defined, but it should at least show the tasks in tasks.json first, and then extend the list once Gulp returns. Our Gulpfile is pretty big, while I expect the parsing of the JSON to be almost instant.

Also, when I already type in the task name and hit enter, VS Code should not wait till the tasks are loaded and instead just run that task directly. The fuzzy searching is not beneficial for the task picker.

It also seems like every character you type into the picker while the tasks are loading will abort and restart the whole process, which doesn't make sense.

data.title: Implement Window/Page scroll commands
data.body:
These commands are needed for Vim:

From https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim/issues/210:

Vim has handy commands for scrolling without moving the cursor, e.g. zt, which scrolls the screen so that the line with the current cursor is placed as the first line. E.g., I often do actions like /main(<CR>zt, so that I can see as much of the main function as possible.

Would it be possible to implement zt, zb and zz?

Thanks!
- [x] Scroll window upwards/downwards by lines (real line) or window size (eg, half window size)

``` javascript
executeCommand('editorScroll', {to: 'up', by: 'line', value: 10, revealCursor?: false});
```
### 'to'
- up
- down
### 'by'
- line
- wrappedLine
- page
- halfPage
### 'revealCursor'
- If `true` reveals the cursor while scrolling otherwise does not.
- [x] Scroll line to a specific position of the window

``` javascript
executeCommand('revealLine', {lineNumber: 10, at: 'top'});
```
### 'at'
- top
- center
- bottom
- [x] Scroll horizontal scrollbar by column numbers.
  Horizontal scrolling is already implemented by cursor move commands. Hence marking this done. See #8997

data.title: #55: Improve result sorting performance
data.body:
A good improvement, time to sort is (sortedResultDuration - unsortedResultDuration) below.

Before:

```
{"fromCache":false,"searchLength":1,"unsortedResultDuration":11682,"sortedResultDuration":22670,"numberOfResultEntries":224197},
{"fromCache":false,"searchLength":1,"unsortedResultDuration":11451,"sortedResultDuration":22369,"numberOfResultEntries":224197},
{"fromCache":false,"searchLength":1,"unsortedResultDuration":11915,"sortedResultDuration":23141,"numberOfResultEntries":224197},
```

After:

```
{"fromCache":false,"searchLength":1,"unsortedResultDuration":11325,"sortedResultDuration":11429,"numberOfResultEntries":224197},
```

data.title: Webpack warnings cannot be matched
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

I am using webpack to build and pack up my application.  Webpack produces warnings in the following format when you accidentally use an import with the wrong case in the file path: (i.e. ./**C**omponents/SomeComponent vs ./**c**omponents/SomeComponent)

```
WARNING in ./src/Components/SomeComponent.tsx
There is another module with an equal name when case is ignored.
This can lead to unexpected behavior when compiling on a filesystem with other case-semantic.
Rename module if multiple modules are expected or use equal casing if one module is expected.
```

Now when I try to use the following problem matcher for this:

```
                {
                    "owner": "webpack",
                    "fileLocation": "relative",
                    "severity": "warning",
                    "pattern": [                        
                        {
                            "regexp": "WARNING in (.*)",
                            "file": 1
                        }
                        ,{
                            "regexp": "(.*)$",
                            "message": 1,
                            "loop": true
                        }
                    ]                   
                }
```

I get the following message when trying to build the project:

> The problem pattern is invalid. It must have at least a file, message and line or location match group.

So it seems that the problem matcher validation logic requires that there is a location (line,col) for a rule to be valid.  Couldn't the default just being the first line / column of a file so that the matcher could handle scenarios like this where its a file in general that produces the warning?

I admit, I feel like Webpack's warning should include a line/col as it is complaining about a specific import.  But it would also be nice to be able to handle plugins that aren't necessarily being good citizens with respects to the output they surface.

data.title: Breakpoints are not resolved properly for symlinked files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set a breakpoint in VS Code to a file which is symlinked from another location ie ( ${workspaceRoot}\node_modules\linked_project\lib\test.js where ${workspaceRoot}\node_modules\linked_project\ is linked to C:\linked_project)
2. The breakpoint is set to node_modules\linked_project\lib\test.js which is never triggered
3. If C:\linked_project\lib\test.js is opened directly from the Open File dialog, breakpoints set are triggered properly
